Cloze

fields: The {{c2::posterior}} pituitary is a collection of nerve axons whose cell bodies are located in {{c1::hypothalamic nuclei}}
{{c2::Hypothalamic}} hormones stimulate or inhibit the release of {{c1::anterior pituitary}} hormones

Six major hormones are secreted by the anterior lobe of the pituitary: 
{{c1::
 1. FSH
 2. LH
 3. ACTH
 4. TSH
 5. Prolactin
 6. Growth hormone
}}
{{c2::Growth hormone}} is synthesized in the {{c1::somatotrophs}} of the anterior lobe of the pituitary gland
thus, it is also called somatotropin or somatotropic hormone

What direct action does growth hormone have on production of insulin-like growth factor (IGF)?

{{c1::Increased}}
Increased IGF aids in increased lean body mass, increased organ size, and increased linear growth
Growth hormone/IGF-1 alters cartilage metabolism to increase {{c1::linear}} growth

- Via an increase of protein synthesis in chondrocytes (stimulates chondrocytes in growth plates)

- in contrast to estrogen, IGF-1 does not accelerate epiphyseal closure

What is the embryonic origin of the anterior pituitary? 

{{c1::Oral ectoderm, specifically from Rathke's pouch}}
Prolactin {{c2::inhibits}} ovulation and spermatogenesis by decreasing synthesis and release of {{c1::GnRH}}

Both ADH and oxytocin are neuropeptides,
 synthesized in hypothalamic neurons and secreted from nerve terminals in the {{c1::posterior pituitary}}
{{c2::Antidiuretic hormone (ADH)}} is packaged with neurophysin {{c1::II}} and glycoprotein
point mutations in neurophysin II underlie most cases of heredtiary hypothalamic diabetes insipidus
The most important physiologic stimulus for increasing antidiuretic hormone (ADH) secretion is {{c1::increased plasma osmolarity}}
sensed by osmoreceptors in the anterior hypothalamus

What receptors sense an increase in plasma osmolarity, providing stimuli to increase ADH secretion?

{{c1::osmoreceptors in the anterior hypothalamus}}
The major action of ADH (vasopressin) is to increase {{c1::water permeability (and thus reabsorption)}} of the principal cells in the {{c2::late distal convoluted tubule}} and {{c2::collecting duct}}
The receptors for ADH on the principal cells of the late distal tubule and collecting duct are {{c1::V2}} receptors

How does ADH increase H2O permeability of the principal cells of the late distal tubule and collecting duct?

{{c1::Increased aquaporin 2 (AQP2) channels via increased cAMP}}
{{c2::Central}} diabetes insipidus is caused by failure of the posterior pituitary to secrete {{c1::ADH}}

- damage to posterior pituitary typically results in transient central DI as hypothalamic nuclei are intact and axonal regeneration / hypertrophy can allow adequate ADH release into the circulation

- damage to hypothalamic nuclei results in loss in vasopressinergic neurons, which often leads to permanent central DI

Which ADH disorder is characterized by low levels of circulating ADH and thus large volumes of dilute urine? 

{{c1::central diabetes insipidus (nephrogenic has high ADH levels)}}
also have increased serum osmolarity and increased Na+ concentration, secondary to decreased water absorption
{{c3::Central}} diabetes insidipus is treated with an {{c1::ADH}} analogue, such as {{c2::dDAVP (desmopressin)}}
In {{c1::nephrogenic diabetes insipidus}}, the principal cells of the collecting duct are unresponsive to {{c2::ADH}} due to a defect in the V2 receptor, Gs protein, or adenylyl cyclase

Which type of diabetes insipidus is characterized by an inability of the posterior pituitary to secrete ADH?

{{c1::central diabetes insipidus}}

Which type of diabetes insipidus is characterized by a lack of response to the ADH secreted by the posterior pituitary?

{{c1::nephrogenic diabetes insipidus}}

Which type of diabetes insipidus is characterized by elevated levels of ADH?

{{c1::nephrogenic diabetes insipidus}}
due to stimulation of secretion by the increased serum osmolarity
{{c2::Nephrogenic}} diabetes insipidus is treated with {{c1::thiazide}} diuretics
results in decreased Na+ reabsorption and water excretion & increased water reabsorption
{{c2::Oxytocin}} causes {{c1::ejection of milk}} from the breast when stimulated by suckling
via stimulating contraction of myoepithelial cells lining the milk ducts
Oxytocin is secreted in response to {{c1::dilation of the cervix}} during labor or orgasm
Oxytocin causes powerful rhythmic contractions of {{c1::uterine smooth}} muscle
during pregnancy, oxytocin receptors in the uterus are up-regulated as parturition approaches
{{c1::Oxytocin}} is a hormone that may be used to induce {{c2::labor}} and reduce {{c3::postpartum bleeding}}
synthetic analog is known as Pitocin, both actions occur due to uterine contraction

Which thyroid hormone (T3 or T4) is more active?

{{c1::T3}}

What is the main thyroid hormone (T3 or T4) that is secreted? 

{{c1::T4}}
High levels of {{c1::I-}} inhibit {{c2::organification}} of I2, and therefore inhibit synthesis of thyroid hormones ({{c3::Wolff-Chaikoff}} effect)

inhibition occurs via transient inhibition of thyroid peroxidase; can be manipulated to protect the thyroid when:

- patients are being given radiography techniques that use I131 (give potassium iodine beforehand to inhibit the incorporation of further iodine in thyroid)

-concern for nuclear emergency prophylaxis
In the circulation, most of the T3 and T4 is bound to {{c1::thyroxine-binding globulin (TBG)}}

only free thyroid hormones are active, thus TBG provides of a large reservoir of circulating thyroid hormones that can be added to the pool of free thyroid hormone

Increased TBG increases T4 and T3 without actual hyperthyroidism

Must check free T4 in order to better reflect biologic activity and clinical relevance

Which thyroid hormone (T4 or T3) binds to nuclear receptor with greater affinity?

{{c1::T3}}
{{c3::Thyrotropin-releasing hormone (TRH)}} acts on thyrotrophs of the anterior pituitary to stimulate the secretion of {{c2::thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH)}}
the other action of TRH is to stimulate prolactin secretion
Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) secretion is decreased in response to {{c1::free T3/T4}}
the anterior lobe contains thyroid deiodinase and thus may convert free T4 to free T3
In addition to TSH, the TSH receptor on thyroid glands may be activated by {{c1::Thyrotropin receptor antibodies (TRAb)}} (Graves disease)
thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulins are antibodies to the TSH receptor

What is the result when thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulins bind to TSH receptors of the thyroid gland?

{{c1::They stimulate secretion of T3 and T4}}

Which thyroid disorder is associated with high concentrations of Thyrotropin receptor antibodies (TRAb)?

{{c1::Graves disease}}

What is the level of TSH in a patient with Graves disease (increased, decreased, or normal)? 

{{c1::Decreased}}
secondary to high circulating levels of thyroid hormones, which inhibit TSH secretion by negative feedback

What effect does excessive I- intake  have on thyroid hormone secretion?

{{c1::Decreases secretion (Wolff-Chaikoff effect)}}
Once T3 is produced inside its target cell, it enters the {{c1::nucleus}} and binds to a {{c1::nuclear}} receptor

Thyroid hormones increase cardiac output 
by inducing synthesis (upregulation) of {{c1::β1 adrenergic}} receptors in the heart

β1 receptors mediate the effects on the SNS to increase HR, contractility, SV, CO

thus B1 blockers can be used to alleviate adrenergic symptoms in a thyroid storm
The most common cause of hyperthyroidism is {{c1::Graves disease}}
other causes include thyroid neoplasm, excessive TSH or TRH secretion, or administration of excessive exogenous thyroid hormone

What are the levels of TSH in hyperthyroidism due to Graves disease or thyroid neoplasm? Why?

{{c1::Decreased due to negative feedback from increased level of free T3}}
The most common cause of hypothyroidism in thyroid first world countries is {{c1::autoimmune or Hashimoto thyroiditis}}
The zona {{c1::fasciculata}} secretes {{c2::glucocorticoids}}, such as {{c2::cortisol}}

Can glucocorticosteroids still be produced if there is absence of cholesterol desmolase, 21β-hydroxylase, 11β-hydroxylase, or 3β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase? 

{{c1::No, a lack of any of these enzymes would block the synthesis of both corticosterone AND cortisol}}
death will ensue without appropriate hormone replacement therapy
Glucocorticoid (cortisol) secretion is {{c1::pulsatile}} and {{c1::diurnal}} (daily) in nature, oscillating with a circadian rhythm

this is a result of the diurnal pattern of CRH and ACTH secretion; diurnal pattern may be lost by coma, blindness, or constant exposure to dark/light -- aldosterone follows a similar secretion pattern
Cortisol levels are highest just before {{c1::awakening}} and lowest in the {{c1::evening}}
in a person that wakes in the morning and sleeps at night
ACTH increases steroid hormone synthesis via stimulation of the enzyme {{c1::cholesterol desmolase}}, thus increasing the conversion of cholesterol to pregnenolone
Chronically elevated levels of ACTH cause {{c1::hypertrophy/hyperplasia}} of the adrenal cortex

How does cortisol effect secretion of CRH from the hypothalamus?

{{c1::inhibits secretion, both directly and indirectly}}
indirectly via effecting the hippocampal neurons which snyapse on the hypothalamus

How does cortisol effect secretion of ACTH from the hypothalamus? 

{{c1::Inhibits secretion, directly}}
Chronic excess levels of cortisol (glucocorticoid) result in decreased levels of {{c1::CRH}} and {{c1::ACTH}} via negative feedback
{{c2::Dexamethasone}} is a synthetic {{c1::glucocorticoid}} that mimics the actions of cortisol, including suppression of ACTH

What is the result of the dexamethasone suppression test in a normal patient?

{{c1::Low-dose dexamethasone inhibits ACTH secretion and consequently cortisol secretion}}

What is the result of a dexamethasone suppression test if the cause of hypercortisolism is an ACTH-secreting tumor of the anterior pituitary?

{{c1::LOW dose of dexamethasone does not suppress cortisol secretion, but HIGH dose does}}
the tumors ACTH secretion is less sensitive to negative feedback

What is the result of a dexamethasone suppression test if the cause of hypercortisolism is an adrenal cortical tumor?

{{c1::neither low nor high dose dexamethasone suppresses cortisol secretion}}
Cortisol (glucocorticoids) up-regulates {{c1::α1}} receptors on arterioles, increasing their sensitivity to {{c2::catecholamines (i.e. norepinephrine and epinephrine)}}
Glucocorticoids (e.g. cortisol) are essential in maintaining {{c1::vascular responsiveness}} to catecholamines
via upregulatin of α1 receptors on arterioles
Cortisol results in an {{c1::increased}} glomerular filtration rate (GFR)
{{c2::Addison}} disease is most commonly caused by {{c1::autoimmune destruction}} of all three zones of the adrenal cortex, which causes acute adrenal crisis
also known as primary adrenocortical insufficiency; primary defect of the adrenal cortex, not of the hypothalamus-hypophysial axis

Which classes of steroid hormones are decreased in Addison disease?

{{c1::all three (glucocorticoids, mineralocorticoids, and androgens)}}

What is the level of ACTH in Addison disease? Why?

{{c1::Increased; low cortisol levels stimulate ACTH secretion by negative feedback}}
One clinical feature of Addison disease is {{c1::hyperkalemia}} (K+ levels)
due to decreased aldosterone levels
Addison disease may present with decreased {{c1::pubic/axillary hair}} and {{c2::libido}} in females due to decreased levels of {{c3::androgens}}

What is the treatment of Addison disease (primary adrenocortical insufficiency)?

{{c1::Replacement of glucocorticoids and mineralocorticoids}}

What is the level of ACTH in secondary adrenocortical insufficiency? Why?

{{c1::Decreased; the disease is a result of decreased ACTH secretion}}
this is an important distinguishing feature from Addison disease and explains why secondary adrenocortical insufficiency does not present with hyperpigmentation
Cushing {{c1::disease}} is the result of chronic excess glucocorticoids caused by {{c2::hypersecretion of ACTH from a pituitary adenoma}}

Which classes of steroid hormones are increased in Cushing syndrome/disease?

{{c1::glucocorticoids (cortisol) +/- androgens}}

What is the level of ACTH in Cushing disease? Why?

{{c1::Increased because the disease is caused by an ACTH-secreting tumor}}

What would the result of a dexamethasone suppression test be in a patient with Cushing disease? 

{{c1::Cortisol response WOULD BE surpressed by high dose dexamethasone}}

What is the treatment for Cushing disease?

{{c1::Removal of the ACTH-secreting tumor}}
{{c1::Conn}} syndrome, or primary hyperaldosteronism, is caused by an {{c2::aldosterone-secreting tumor}}
{{c1::21β-hydroxylase}} deficiency is the most common cause of congenital adrenal hyperplasia
belongs to a group of disorders characterized by adrenogenital syndrome

What is the level of ACTH in 21β-hydroxylase deficiency? Why?

{{c1::Increased, due to decreased feedback inhibition from cortisol}}
leads to adrenocortical hyperplasia

What clinical features are seen in 21β-hydroxylase deficiency that are a result of increased androgen levels in females? 

{{c1::Masculinization (clitoral enlargement, early appearance of pubic/axillary hair)}}
other clinical features are those of glucocorticoid and mineralocorticoid deficiency

What is the treatment for 21β-hydroxylase deficiency?

{{c1::Replacement therapy of both glucocorticoids and mineralocorticoids}}

Which adrenal cortex deficiency results in shunting towards the androgen synthesis pathway?

{{c1::21β-hydroxylase deficiency}}
{{c1::Primary hyperparathyroidism}} is characterized by hypercalcemia, hypophosphatemia, and increased circulating levels of PTH
hypercalcemia and hypophosphatemia are results of elevated PTH levels
Pituitary {{c1::adenoma}} is a benign tumor of the anterior pituitary cells
Pituitary adenomas may be {{c1::functional}} (hormone producing) or {{c1::nonfunctional}} (silent)
If functioning, results in hyper----emia of whatever the hormone cell tumor produces (ex lactotroph --> hyperprolactinemia)
Pituitary adenoma may present with {{c1::bitemporal hemianopsia}} due to compression of the {{c2::optic chiasm}}
tumor sits in sella turcica, which is adjacent to optic chiasm, these patients will present with a history of clumsiness and visual changes
Pituitary adenoma may present with {{c1::hypopituitarism}} due to compression of normal pituitary tissue

What is the most common type of functional pituitary adenoma? 

{{c1::Prolactinoma}}
In females, prolactinoma presents as {{c1::galactorrhea}} and {{c2::amenorrhea}}
due to increased lactogenesis and decreased GnRH
In males, prolactinoma presents as headache, decreased {{c1::libido}}, and infertility

due to inhibition of GnRH release and mass effect; no galactorrhea

HOWEVER, men with prolactinomas are more likely to present at an advanced stage with mass-effect symptoms
Hypopituitarism may be caused by {{c1::Sheehan}} syndrome, which is a {{c2::pregnancy}}-related {{c3::infarction}} of the pituitary gland

- pregnancy induced growth of pituitary (estrogen stimulates hyperplasia of lactotrophs), as well as the minimal vascularity of the pituitary gland, make the pituitary susceptible to hypoperfusion

- therefore, heavy postpartum bleeding will manifest with hypoperfusion of the kidney
Pregnancy-related infarction of the pituitary gland (Sheehan syndrome) often occurs following {{c1::postpartum bleeding}}
blood loss increases risk of infarction
Symptoms of Sheehan syndrome include poor {{c1::lactation}}, loss of {{c1::pubic hair}}, and fatigue
also may have absent menstruation and cold intolerance
Hypopituitarism may be caused by {{c1::empty sella}} syndrome, which may occur due to trauma or congenital defect of the sella
Empty sella syndrome occurs due to atrophy or compression, and ultimately destruction of the {{c1::pituitary}} gland
for example, herniation of the arachnoid and CSF into the sella
Empty sella syndrome is characterized by {{c1::absence}} of the pituitary gland on imaging

What demographic is more commonly affected by empty sella syndrome? 

{{c1::Obese women}}
{{c1::Central}} diabetes insipidus is characterized by polyuria and polydipsia with an inability to {{c3::concentrate}} urine due to {{c2::lack of ADH}}
{{c1::Nephrogenic}} diabetes insipidus is characterized by polyuria and polydipsia with an inability to {{c3::concentrate}} urine due to {{c2::lack of response to ADH}}
Etiologies of {{c1::central}} diabetes insipidus include pituitary tumor, autoimmune, trauma, surgery, and ischemic encephalopathy

- Autoimmune can be against posterior pituitary or against ADH

- Trauma can be neurosurgery (9% of cases), head injury (17% of cases - ex. basilar skull fracture)

- Benign Suprasellar tumor (20% of cases) / trauma to posterior pituitary / pituitary stalk / head trauma depletes posterior pituitary of ADH stores

- noninfectious granulomas (sarcoidosis, langerhans cell histiocytosis)

- idiopathic (25% of cases)

- hemochromatosis

- genetic mutation (AD mutation in neurophysin II- carrier for ADH as it descends the neurohypophysis)
{{c2::Nephrogenic}} diabetes insipidus is often caused by {{c1::ADH receptor}} mutations
{{c1::Nephrogenic}} diabetes insipidus may be caused by drugs such as {{c2::lithium}} and {{c3::demeclocycline}}
demeclocycline is an ADH antagonist
Both central and nephrogenic diabetes insipidus are characterized by urine specific gravity < {{c1::1.006}}
A urine specific gravity test compares the density of urine to the density of water. This quick test can help determine how well your kidneys are diluting your urine.
Both central and nephrogenic diabetes insipidus are characterized by {{c1::low}} urine osmolality
Both central and nephrogenic diabetes insipidus are characterized by serum osmolality {{c1::> 290 mOsm/kg}}
due to decreased ability to retain H2O , also causes hypernatremia
Both central and nephrogenic diabetes insipidus are characterized by blood hyperosmotic volume {{c1::contraction}}
lack of ADH causes excess water excretion and thus volume contraction
Central diabetes insipidus is characterized by {{c1::low}} levels of ADH
Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus is characterized by {{c1::normal}} or {{c1::elevated}} levels of ADH
Treatment for central diabetes insipidus includes hydration and {{c1::desmopressin}}, which is an ADH analog
Treatment for nephrogenic diabetes insipidus includes hydration and {{c1::HCTZ}}, which is a thiazide diuretic
may also use indomethacin and amiloride
Diagnosis of diabetes insipidus is aided by the {{c1::water deprivation}} test
In diabetes insipidus, the water deprivation test fails to {{c1::increase}} urine osmolality
**osmolality will increase in central diabetes insipidus with administration of an ADH analog
SIADH is characterized by {{c1::euvolemic}} (volume) {{c1::hyponatremia}} (Na+ level) with continued urinary Na+ excretion
body responds to water retention with decreased aldosterone, causing normal volumes (euvolemic) but decreased sodium (hyponatremia)
In SIADH, serum Na+ levels must be corrected slowly to prevent {{c1::osmotic demyelination}} syndrome
formerly known as central pontine myelinolysis
Treatment of SIADH includes water restriction and {{c1::demeclocycline}}, which is a tetracycline

other treatments include IV hypertonic saline and conivaptan/tolvaptan (ADH receptor antagonists)

Demeclocycline and lithium act on the collecting tubule cell to diminish its responsiveness to ADH, thereby increasing water excretion [1,38-40]. In patients with bipolar disorder who are treated with chronic lithium therapy, nephrogenic diabetes insipidus develops in up to 20 to 40 percent

What demographic is most commonly associated with Graves disease?

{{c1::Women of childbearing age; often presents during stress (e.g. childbirth)}}

What type of goiter is associated with Graves disease?

{{c1::Diffuse goiter}}
Graves disease is associated with {{c1::exopthalmos}} which occurs due to activation of retro-orbital {{c2::fibroblasts}}

- activated T cells release cytokines (TNFa, IFN-y) which activate fibroblasts (along with TRab to a lesser degree), causing increased secretions of glycosaminoglycans

- GAG deposition leads to osmotic muscle swelling, muscle inflammation, and increased adipocyte count --> eyes being pushed out, dysfunction of extraocular muscles causes restricted extraocular movements and diplopia

visible appearance causes appearance of a "stare"

{{c1::Thyroid storm (Thyrotoxicosis)}} is a serious complication that occurs when hyperthyroidism is untreatened and 
worsened in the setting of acute stress (e.g. infection, trauma, surgery)

patient has a preexisting hyperthyroid disease (grave's or toxic multinodular goiter)

acute stress + hyperthyroidism leads to massive catecholamine surge --> symptoms
Thyroid storm presents with agitation, delirium, fever, {{c2::diarrhea}}, coma, and {{c1::tachyarrhythmia}} (cause of death)

What serum marker may be elevated in thyroid storm due to increased bone turnover?

{{c1::Alkaline phosphatase}}
May also see increased LFTs

What are the "4 P's" used to treat thyroid storm?

 1. {{c1::Propranolol}} (a beta-blocker)
 2. {{c1::Propylthiouracil}} 
 3. {{c2::Prednisolone}} (a corticosteroid)
 4. {{c2::Potassium iodide (MUST be given after 1 hour after PTU)}} (Lugol iodine)

Propylthiouracil binds to thyroid peroxidase and thereby inhibits the conversion of iodide to iodine. Thyroid peroxidase normally converts iodide to iodine (via hydrogen peroxide as a cofactor) and also catalyzes the incorporation of the resulting iodide molecule onto both the 3 and/or 5 positions of the phenol rings of tyrosines found in thyroglobulin. Thyroglobulin is degraded to produce thyroxine (T4) and tri-iodothyronine (T3), which are the main hormones produced by the thyroid gland. Therefore propylthiouracil effectively inhibits the production of new thyroid hormones.

PI = excess iodine blocks T4/T3 synthesis, must give one hour after ptu otherwise it can exacerbate the symptoms 

Glucorticoids These agents block conversion of T4 to T3. The use of corticosteroids has been associated with improved survival. Stress doses are required to replace accelerated production and degradation of cortisol induced by TH.

This agent is used to inhibit TH release from the thyroid gland
{{c2::Myxedema}} is the accumulation of {{c1::glycosaminoglycans}} in the skin and soft tissue; it is most often associated with {{c3::hypothyroidism}}

the major GAG is hyaluronic acid, which then draws water out into the deposit (in interstitial spaces of the dermis; due to osmotic pressure) and causes swelling (water retention; usually facial / periorbital swelling but can be generalized nonpitting edema)

a myxedema coma = coma from hypothyroidism

In hypothyroidism patients, myxedema 
commonly affects the {{c1::larynx}} (causing deep voice) and {{c1::tongue}} (causing enlarged tongue)
Hashimoto thyroiditis is associated with HLA-{{c1::DR5}} and HLA-{{c1::DR3}}

What is the most common cause of hypothyroidism in regions where iodine levels are adequate?

{{c1::Hashimoto thyroiditis}}

other causes include:
- iodine deficiency (Endemic Goiter  - especially in Southeast Asia and Africa)
- Wolff-Chaikoff effect (iodine excess)
- goitrogens (e.g. lithium, amiodarone)

iodine deficiency shown below
Initially, Hashimoto thyroiditis presents as {{c1::hyperthyroidism}} due to thyrotoxicosis during follicular rupture
ultimately progresses to hypothyroidism (decreased T4, increased TSH)

Which two antibodies are associated with Hashimoto thyroiditis? 

{{c1::Anti-thyroglobulin}} and {{c2::anti-thyroid peroxidase (anti-microsomal)}}
these are a sign of thyroid damage, not the cause of damage
Histologically, Hashimoto thyroiditis may have {{c1::Hurthle}} cells, which are eosinophilic metaplastic cells that line the follicles

Does Hashimoto thyroiditis present with a tender or nontender thyroid?

{{c1::Nontender}}
and mildly enlarged
Thyroid nodules are more likely to be {{c1::benign}} than {{c1::malignant}} (benign or malignant)
US should be performed with consideration for FNA
Thyroid nodules may be studied using {{c1::131I}} radioactive uptake studies

Radioactive iodine scan for “hot” or “cold” nodules

Overactive areas are “hot” and show up darker than normal tissue. Underactive areas are “cold” and show up lighter than normal tissue. Malignancy associated with cold nodules
Thyroid {{c1::papillary}} carcinoma may be lined by cells with clear, '{{c2::Orphan Annie eye}}' nuclei

nuclei with central clearing, sometimes described as "ground glass" nuclei

Treated with thyroidectomy, typically prognonsis is good.
Type {{c1::1}} diabetes mellitus is characterized by insulin deficiency
Type {{c1::2}} diabetes mellitus is characterized by insulin resistance
Type 1 diabetes mellitus is due to {{c1::autoimmune destruction}} of pancreatic {{c2::β}} cells by {{c3::anti-glutamic acid decarboxylase}} antibodies
autoantibodies against insulin may be present in blood (sign of damage); may be seen before disease develops

What is the level of insulin in a patient with type 2 diabetes (elevated, decreased, normal)? 

{{c1::Variable; increased early in disease, but may be decreased later in disease due to beta cell exhaustion}}
Type 1 diabetes is associated with HLA-{{c1::DR3}} and HLA-{{c1::DR4}}

Why do patients with diabetes mellitus present with polyuria and polydipsia? 

{{c1::Excess glucose is filtered into the urine and pulls water with it}}

What is the most common type of diabetes mellitus?

{{c1::Type 2}}

What is the diagnostic cutoff for HbA1c for a diagnosis of diabetes mellitus? 

{{c1::>6.5%}}

What is the diagnostic cutoff for fasting plasma glucose for a diagnosis of diabetes mellitus?

{{c1::>126 mg/dL}}
after fasting for >8 hours

What is the diagnostic cutoff for the 2-hour oral glucose tolerance test for a diagnosis of diabetes mellitus?

{{c1::> 200 mg/dL}}
2 hours after consumption of 75g of glucose in water
One of the most feared complications of type 1 diabetes is {{c1::diabetic ketoacidosis}}
Diabetic ketoacidosis is associated with a {{c1::fruity}} breath odor due to exhaled {{c2::acetone}}
Diabetic ketoacidosis is associated with {{c1::Kussmaul}} respirations, which is rapid/deep breathing to compensate for metabolic {{c2::acidosis}}

What type of acidosis will a patient with diabetic ketoacidosis experience?

{{c1::high anion gap metabolic acidosis}}

Will a diabetic ketoacidosis patient present with hyper- or hypo-glycemia?

{{c1::hyperglycemia (usually >300 mg/dL)}}

What fungal infection is a feared complication in a diabetic ketoacidosis patient?

{{c1::mucormycosis (usually caused by Rhizopus infection)}}

What is the treatment for diabetic ketoacidosis?

IV {{c1::fluids}}, {{c1::insulin}}, and {{c1::K+ (to replete intracellular stores)}}
Remember, fix volume status first!
One of the most feared complications of type 2 diabetes is {{c1::hyperosmolar hyperglycemia non-ketotic syndrome}}
hyperglycemia causes excessive osmotic diuresis, leading to dehydration and possibly coma

What demographic is most commonly associated with hyperosmolar hyperglycemia non-ketotic syndrome? 

{{c1::Elderly type 2 diabetics, especially with limited ability to drink}}
Hyperosmolar hyperglycemic non-ketotic syndrome often presents with glucose levels > {{c1::600}} mg/dL and increased serum osmolarity (> 320 mOsm/kg)

Does hyperosmolar hyperglycemia non-ketotic syndrome present with acidosis? Why? 

{{c1::No, ketone production is inhibited by presence of insulin}}

HHS is usually precipitated by an infection,<sup>[6]</sup> myocardial infarction, stroke or another acute illness. A relative insulin deficiency leads to a serum glucose that is usually higher than 33 mmol/L (600 mg/dL), and a resulting serum osmolarity that is greater than 320 mOsm. This leads to excessive urination (more specifically an osmotic diuresis), which, in turn, leads to volume depletion and hemoconcentration that causes a further increase in blood glucose level. Ketosis is absent because the presence of some insulin inhibits hormone-sensitive lipase mediated fat tissue breakdown.

{{c1::intense IV fluids and insulin therapy}}

The clinical features of primary aldosteronism are, in part, determined by the renal actions of aldosterone. The primary effect of aldosterone is to increase the number of open sodium channels in the luminal membrane of the principal cells in the cortical collecting tubule, leading to increased sodium reabsorption [9]. The ensuing loss of cationic sodium makes the lumen electronegative, thereby creating an electrical gradient that favors the secretion of cellular potassium into the lumen through potassium channels in the luminal membrane.
{{c1::Primary}} hyperaldosteronism is characterized by high aldosterone and {{c2::low}} renin

Hypertension - The pathogenesis of hypertension in Cushing's syndrome is multifactorial and not fully understood; however, the following factors may be important []:

●Increased peripheral vascular sensitivity to adrenergic agonists [].

●Increased hepatic production of renin substrate (angiotensinogen); based on this observation, one consensus paper suggests that angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors should be considered the first-line treatment of hypertension in Cushing's syndrome patients [].

●Activation of renal tubular type 1 (mineralocorticoid) receptors by cortisol (this mechanism applies mainly to patients with severe hypercortisolism, which is usually due to ectopic ACTH secretion) [].
Clinical features of Addison disease include hyponatremia, hypovolemia, hypercalcemia and hyperkalemia, due to lack of {{c1::mineralocorticoids}}

- If measured PCO2 < predicted PCO2 --> concomitant respiratory alkalosis

{{c2::Osmotic Demyelination Syndrome}} is also referred to as {{c1::Central pontine myelinolysis}}
Rapid correction of {{c1::hypo}}-natremia results in {{c2::Osmotic Demyelination Syndrome}}

This is caused by overly rapid intravenous correction of hyponatremia - 
"from low to high, your pons will die"

In context of chronic low plasma sodium, the brain compensates by decreasing the levels of osmolytes (inositol, betaine, glutamine, glucose) so that brain cells can remain relatively isotonic and not absorb too much fluid 

With correction of hyponatremia with IV fluids, extracellular tonicity increases, followed by an increase in intracellular tonicity (by cell making more intracellular osmolytes)

IF correction is too rapid, not enough time is allowed for brains cells to adjust to new tonicity
- Not enough time to increase osmolytes
- Therefore, the intracellular water will be pulled out to balance the extracellular tonicity
- This can lead to cellular dysfunction and central pontine myelinolysis
- Myelin sheaths in the pons becomes damaged
Rapid correction of {{c1::hyper}}-natremia results in {{c2::cerebral edema/herniation}}

In a systematic review and meta-analysis of six trials with 587 participants, glucocorticoid-treated patients with GBS showed no significant difference in disability grade compared with patients who were not treated with glucocorticoids [23]. {{c1::Lactulose}}

Lactulose is metabolized in the colon by colonic bacteria to monosaccharides, and then to volatile fatty acids, hydrogen, and methane. Lactulose reduces intestinal ammonia production and absorption in three ways. First, the colonic metabolism of sugars causes a laxative effect via an increase in intraluminal gas formation and osmolality which leads to a reduction in transit time and intraluminal pH. This laxative effect is also beneficial for constipation.[7] Next, lactulose promotes increased uptake of ammonia by colonic bacteria which utilize the trapped colonic ammonia as a nitrogen source for protein synthesis. The reduction of intestinal pH facilitates this process, which favors the conversion of ammonia (NH3) produced by the gut bacteria, to ammonium (NH4+),[8][9][10] an ionized form of the molecule, unable to cross biological membranes. Finally, lactulose also causes a reduction in intestinal production of ammonia. The acidic pH destroys urease-producing bacteria involved in the production of ammonia.  The unabsorbed disaccharide also inhibits intestinal glutaminase activity, which blocks the intestinal uptake of glutamine, and its metabolism to ammonia.

{{c1::Euthyroid sick}} syndrome is an apparent alteration of thyroid hormone level with normal thyroid gland function seen in {{c2::critically ill}} patients
Aka Non-Thyroidal Illness Syndrome; seen in cancer, pneumonia, cardiac disease, sepsis

Most commonly, patients with euthyroid sick syndrome will have:

- serum TSH {{c1::normal}}
- total serum T4 {{c1::normal}}
- total serum T3 {{c1::↓}}
- reverse T3 {{c1::↑}}

Euthyroid sick syndrome (ESS) is a state of adaptation or dysregulation of thyrotropic feedback control[1] wherein the levels of T3 and/or T4 are abnormal, but the thyroid gland does not appear to be dysfunctional.

Patients with severe Euthyroid Sick Syndrome may have low free and total T4 levels AND TSH levels

this is because in critical illness there is decreased activity of D1/D2 5-monodeiodinase activity (normally T4 --> T3, and rT3 --> T2), and increased activity of D3 5' monodeiodinase (normally T4 --> rT3)

{{c1::Hypothyroidism}}

a-glucosidase inhibitors are not recommended if {{c1::kidney}} function is impaired

Taken orally, they inhibit the upper gastrointestinal enzymes (alpha-glucosidases) that convert complex polysaccharide carbohydrates into monosaccharides in a dose-dependent fashion. Patients with diabetic neuropathy present with a slowly progressive decrease in vibratory sensation, {{c1::proprioception}}, and {{c2::temperature}} sensation

Capillary basement membrane thickening and capillary closure occurs over time
Occluded vasa nevorum capillaries lead to demyelination and diminished nerve conduction
Patients with early diabetic neuropathy typically have decreased {{c1::ankle}} reflexes

The most important steps in working up a metabolic alkalosis are:

- determining the patients {{c1::volume status}} for saline responsiveness
- checking the urine {{c2::chloride}} levels

- vomiting / nasogastric aspiration present with low urine chloride and volume loss (saline responsive)

- prior diuretic use can lead to a low urine chloride state that is saline responsive, and current diuretic use can lead to a high urine chloride state when diuretic use is ongoing (also saline responsive)

- mineralocorticoid excess state will result in a high urine chloride and hyper volemia that thus will not be saline responsive

Cyanide poisoning is usually due to {{c1::inhalation}} injury

Ex. due to fires, cyanide is released in the burning of plastics, wool, and plants (Ex. cassava)

Another cause is rodenticides ("gopher goiter")
Cyanide inhibits {{c1::aerobic}} metabolism, resulting in hypoxia unresponsive to {{c2::supplemental O2}}
Decreased aerobic metabolism leads to increased anaerobic metabolism --> lactic acidosis and increased AG metabolic acidosis
Patients with cyanide poisoning present with an "almond" breath odor and {{c1::reddish}} skin discoloration

Patients also are tachypneic, tachycardic, and often are nauseated, vomit, are confused and weak

This is rapidly fatal if untreated
Many patients with inhalation injury present secondary to {{c1::burns}}, CO inhalation, cyanide poisoning, or {{c2::arsenic}} poisoning
Patients with prolonged, untreated obstructive sleep apnea can develop {{c1::pulmonary hypertension}} and a resultant right heart failure

- Each nocturnal episode of reduced ventillation causes transient hypercapnia and hypoxemia, which leads to reflexive systemic and pulmonary vasoconstriction, endothelial dysfunction , and sympathetic cardiac stimulation
Obstructive sleep apnea is due to relaxation of {{c1::pharyngeal muscle tone}} during sleep
This leads to closure of the upper airway; resulting in PO2 declining and PCO2 rising until chemoreceptors in carotid body / brainsteam trigger arousal and pharyngeal tone returns

In this form of sleep apnea; hyperapnea lowers the CO2 level and then over responds (due to delayed detection / response systems) and then shut downs breathing for a period of time (apnea) before hyperapnea occurs again
Patients with cyanide poisoning have a {{c1::narrowing}} of the venous-arterial PO2 gradient
This is because the tissue is unable to extract arterial oxygen

Hypernatremia is characterized by a serum sodium {{c1::> 145}}
Hyponatremia is characterized by a serum sodium {{c1::< 135}}
{{c1::Sensible}} fluid losses are those the person is aware of
such as through wound drainage, GI tract losses (n/v/d) and urination.
{{c1::Insensible}} fluid losses may occur without the person's awareness.
Insensible losses occur daily through the skin and lungs.  Increase in fevers, hyperhidrosis, hypercatolic states (such as in sepsis).
Increased {{c1::thirst and water intake}} is the first defense against {{c2::hypernatremia }}
{{c3::Pseudo/Iso-Osmolar Hyponatremia}} is caused by {{c1::hyperlipidemia}} and {{c2::hyperproteinemia.}}

The total body sodium is not changed, but due to severely abnormal proteinemia or lipid states, the serum Na is read out as low, when in fact it is appropriate.

Multiple myeloma for instance can lead to hyponatremia in an acute,initial presentation, prior to any treatment.
{{c1::Exercise associated Hyponatremia}} is a {{c2::hypoosomlar hyponatremia}} caused by {{c3::replacement of insensible losses with free water.}}
Common in untrained runners
{{c3::Cerebral Salt Wasting}} is characterized by urine sodium {{c1::> 120}} and Urine osmolarity {{c2::> 300}}

leads to impaired Sympathetic mediated Na and water resorption at the proximal tubule.

- seen with{{c2:: lead poisoning}}, {{c3::sideroblastic}} anemia, and {{c4::myelodysplastic syndromes}}

Sideroblastic anemia, or sideroachrestic anemia, is a form of anemia in which the bone marrow produces ringed sideroblasts rather than healthy red blood cells (erythrocytes).
 
Myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS) are a group of cancers in which immature blood cells in the bone marrow do not mature and therefore do not become healthy blood cells.[3] Early on, there are typically no symptoms.[3] Later symptoms may include feeling tired, shortness of breath, easy bleeding, or frequent infections.[3] Some types may develop into acute myeloid leukemia.[3]

For every 1g/dL drop in serum {{c1::albumin}} you must increase anion gap by {{c2::2.5 }}
Each 1 mEq/L rise in HCO3 from {{c2::24}}, will result in a rise in PaCO2 by {{c1::0.7 mm Hg}}
In respiratory acidosis  {{c3:: < 2 days}}, For each {{c1::10 mm Hg}} increase in PaCO2, thereis a {{c2::1 mEq/L}} rise in HCO3
In chronic respiratory acidosis {{c3::> 3 days}}, For each {{c1::10}} mm Hg increases in PaCO2,there is an expected {{c2::4 mEq/L}} increase in HCO3
Kidneys compensate more
In Primary Alkalosis compensation {{c1::< 2 days}} For each {{c2::10 mm Hg}} decrease in PaCO2, there is a {{c3::2 mEq/L}} decrease in HCO3

Therefore, if HCO3 is higher than expected, there is an additional metabolic alkalosis present.

If HCO3 is lower than expected, there is an additional metabolic acidosis present.
In Primary Alkalosis, Chronic compensation {{c1::> 3 days}} For each {{c2::10 mm Hg}} decrease in PaCO2, there is a {{c3::4 mEq/L}} decrease in HCO3

Therefore, if HCO3 is higher than expected,there is an additional metabolic alkalosis present.

If HCO3 is lower than expected, there is an additional metabolic acidosis present.
Delta AG/Delta HCO3- = {{c1::1-2}} normally

If Delta/Delta is {{c1::<}} 1, there is an additional
{{c2::non anion gap metabolic acidosis}} present.
If Delta/Delta is {{c1::> 2}}, there is an additional {{c2::metabolic alkalosis}} present.
